titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Douglas Crase and Frank Polach Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:02

did.unittitle: Douglas Crase and Frank Polach papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings, correspondence, photographs, research materials, artwork, and other papers by, to, or relating to Douglas Crase and Frank Polach. Also includes materials materials relating to Rupert Barnaby and Dwight Ripley.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Granary Books, Inc. on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund and the Martin Greenblatt Foundation Book Fund in American Literature, 2014.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
Box 86 (film): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Douglas Crase and Frank Polach Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Douglas Crase and Frank Polach Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

bioghist.head: Douglas Crase and Frank Polach
bioghist.p: Douglas Crase is an American poet and writer. His husband, Frank Polach, is a poet, gardener, and former University Librarian at Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey.

bioghist.head: Dwight Ripley and Rupert Barneby
bioghist.p: Dwight Ripley was an English artist and patron of the arts associated with the New York School and the Tibor de Nagy Gallery. His life partner was Rupert Barneby, an English botanist.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Douglas Crase. "A Voice like the Day." Corrected mss. Essay on James Schuyler published in Poetry 163, no. 4 (January 1994); James Schuyler. The Morning of the Poem, 1980. Bound uncorrected page proof with penciled annotations by Crase; James Schuyler. The Morning of the Poem, 1980. Schuyler has written and inscribed the four-page poem "For Frank" on the book's front end papers, March 19, 1980. The book includes the poem "Dining Out with Doug and Frank (for Frank Polach); James Schuyler. The Morning of the Poem, 1980. Photocopy of manuscript with assorted correspondence regarding which poems were to be included; The "Queen Anne" cherry issue Frank to di Capra. Research done by Frank Polach for a Schuyler poem; Reviews of The Morning of the Poem including Charles North review from L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E with note from North; John Ashbery manuscripts and proofs (some with notes by Crase). Including A Wave, Knocking Around (published as As We Know), Houseboat Days; Assorted reviews and publications.

did.unittitle: Darragh Park, pencil drawing in frame.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: view from James Schuyler's window at Chelsea Hotel. In frame and inscribed to Douglas from Park, November 1995. The drawing was used for the cover of James Schuyler and Darragh Park's Two Journals (Tibor de Nagy Editions, 1995).

scopecontent.p: Published poems - "Home in the Rain" in James Schulyer and Charles North's Broadway: A Poets and Painters Anthology (1979). "Brave Like Their Fathers" in Poetry Now, 1978. "Small Craft Warnings" in The World, no. 32, 1979; Rutgers University Library - Multiple folders with items related to Frank Polach's employment at Rutgers University; New York Botanical Garden - Multiple folders with items related to Frank Polach's publications and employment at The New York Botanical Garden; ColumbiaAppl.; College transcripts, etc. Transcripts, GAPSFAS, GRE. Who's Who in the East UCD Placement; 4-H, 1963; Genetics of Pathogenicity and Sexuality in Phytophthora capsici - Bound dissertation. University of California Davis, 1971.; Wellston High School Yearbook, 1962 - Frank is named "Mr. WHS" (outstanding senior).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs, 19741992 - Black & white and color snapshots, approx. 50 envelopes. Photographs were primarily taken at Robert Dash's home in Sagaponack, Long Island. Photographic negatives and contact sheets, ca. 19761997 Black & white and color negatives, 3 3-ring binders. Negatives and contact sheets primarily taken at Robert Dash's home in home in Sagaponack, Long Island. Also included are snapshots from Frank and Douglas' Chelsea and Carley Brook homes and elsewhere; Magazines and clippings - Approx. 10 magazines and assorted clippings about Robert Dash.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
Scope and Contents
Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rupert Barneby. "Astragalus striatiflorus," ca. 194344. Black and white photograph in frame.; "Astragalus striatiflorus M. E. Jones on dune beneath sandstone cliffs, near Kenab, Utah" is typewritten caption pasted on framed photograph. Rupert Barneby. "Cymopterus megacephalus," ca. 194145. Black and white photograph in frame.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rupert Barneby. "Gilia ripleyi" April 194o, graphite drawing in frame. According to personal correspondence with Douglas, this was "drawn in a motel near Death Valley in April 1940. It was the first new species Rupert and Dwight ever located, although Rupert was not able to publish its scientific description until 1942. By this time he had already published their finding of Cymopterus ripleyi, which thus became their first published new species. Both publications were in Leaflets of Western Botany. The Gilia had a special place in Rupert's heart. It has since been removed from the genus Gilia and renamed Aliciella ripleyi."; Rupert Barneby. "Self-Portrait," 1944. Collage in frame.; Rupert Barneby. "Portrait of Dwight Ripley," 1944. Collage in frame. "Self-Portrait" and "Portrait of Dwight Ripley" can be viewed as "family portraits." They are created in the style of French poet, critic and collagist Georges Hugnet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Cymopterus megacephalus M. E. Jones on talus under cliffs near Navajo Bridge, Coconino Co., Arizona" is typewritten caption pasted on framed photograph. Rupert Barneby. "Arctomecon humilis," ca. 1941. 3 black and white framed photographs. Also known as the Dwarf Bearclaw Poppy. Rupert and Dwight collected the plant in 1941 and 1942.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rupert Barneby. Dwight Ripley at Frenchman Flat, May 13, 1941. Taken on the day that Cymopterus ripleyi var. saniculoides was found. Framed copy of black and white photograph.

did.unittitle: Citations, plaques and awards and other material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Citations, plaques and awards presented to Rupert Barneby; Paired photographs of Douglas Crase and Frank Polach along with photograph of Alfonso Ossorio sculpture (Rupert Barneby designed the arboretum at The Creeks, East Hampton, N.Y. where the sculptures were displayed. The photographs of Douglas and Frank were always displayed in Rupert's bedroom in his Botanical Garden loft. Polish language newspapers in which Dwight Ripley's poems were published during World War II; Other assorted items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Citations, plaques and awards presented to Rupert Barneby.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tufa - Douglas writes of this piece of tufa in Both: "In Rupert's loft there were many curious objects. One that holds my attention in retrospect consisted of a tablet-sized platform, as for a bonsai arrangement, on which sat a porous gray rock that might have been the scale model of a malevolent asteroid. It was a chunk of tufa, the calcareous (as in limestone) deposit from springs and streams that is favored in the rock garden or in the alpine house by plants like Lepidium nanum, is coveted therefore by the rock gardener, and from which Rupert and Dwight constructed their rock-and-tufa cliff at the Spinney."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The larger vasculum was used in 1941 and later when they discovered Cymopterus ripleyi and other plants in Nevada.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The smaller and ornate vasculum was used by Dwight and Rupert on expeditions to Spain and North Africa prior to 1939. It held many samples, including Limonium asparagoides that brought back from Algeria.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dylan Thomas Fund. Letter to Dwight Ripley. Dec. 8. 1953. In frame. Letter on Intercultural Publications Inc. stationery thanking Dwight for his "magnificent contribution to The Dylan Thomas Fund. Signed by Tennessee Williams, Thornton Wilder, Arthur Miller, Marianne Moore, W. H. Auden and Wallace Stevens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Barbara Ertter. Rupert Barneby with colleagues, Independence Mountains, Nevada, June 24, 1981. This is a framed copy print. According to Douglas this "is the only photo so far located of Rupert collecting with colleagues after Dwight's death."; Joan Leigh-Fermor. "House party in Sussex, 1935." Framed copy photograph from Clive Fisher, Cyril Connolly: The Life and Times of England's Most Controversial Literary Critic, (1995).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John Button. "Nude portrait of Joe LeSeur" in frame, ca. early 1950s? Dylan Thomas Fund. Letter to Dwight Ripley. Dec. 8. 1953. In frame.; Unidentified photographer. "Dwight Ripley," photographic portrait taken at the Plaza Hotel, NYC, ca. 1944.
